page.title: 06CREWE YESTERDAY
page.content: I interviewed Mrs Woodward who lives in Crewe. She has lived here for eighty-two years. Crewe used to be a quiet place with little traffic. Fields were plentiful; a small railway town was all it was. Now it's expanded incredibly into a busy little town where bustle is never-ending. It was bombed in the war, especially Rolls Royce. Some people were killed. Many modern appliances, electrical ones mainly, weren't around then. The first job she had was in Doodies in Mill Street. She made picture frames. Her first wage was thirteen shillings and nine pence. Night-time amusement was popular and plentiful.
